transcript.text:
Hello everyone, today, quick holiday video
with a "postal card" format

which is some kind of a continuation
of my video about water properties.

Today we'll ask ourselves
"why do ice cubes cool down drinks ?"
Well...
because they are cold.

Thank you for watching this video,
if you enjoyed it, feel free to share it...
No, just kidding.

In fact we are going to see the reason
for which ice cubes cool down drinks,
and it isn't because they are cold.

Put differently, an ice cube
which would be at -10°C (14°F),
wouldn't cool down much more than one at 0°C (32°F).

So to understand this, we have to come back
to the idea of cooling something.
When we put together a warm body and a cold body,

some heat will be transferred
from the hot body to the cold one

and this ability of the cold body to absorb
heat by increasing its temperature,
it is called 'heat capacity'.

For ice, the heat capacity is nearly
2 joules (J) per gram, per degree.
Which means that if we pick a 10 grams ice cube,
it will absorb 20 J for each more degree.

For example, it changes from -10°C to 0°C
so it increases its temperature by 10°C,

in total, it would have absorbed 200 J,
so it will take 200 J from my drink.
Now what we need to see is that once the ice is at 0°C,
it won't stop there, it will melt.
And the fact that the ice melts, it also takes heat.

Meaning that to melt, the ice cube
has to take heat from the drink.

And the amount of heat it takes at this stage
is called 'fusion heat',
which is nearly 330 J per gram.
That means that my 10 grams ice cube
will take 3300 J to melt.

So if we total this, my ice that changes
from -10°C to 0°C takes 200 J
and then the simple fact of melting takes 3300 J.

You see that almost all the cooling power
of my ice cube
come from the fact that it melts.

That's why "ice cubes" that don't melt
(for example in stone)
will have a significantly worse cooling power.
So it works not well, unless they are pretty massive,
they are very cold and you put a lot of it.

That idea that there is a change of status
and that there is heat transfers associated,

is found in many other situations, for example,
when you've got water on your skin

that evaporates because there is wind,
you are cold, that's for the same reason.

It is also found in the other way,
for example with foot-warmers
that can give you heat for a while.

They are made in a substance
that is commonly sodium acetate.
And this substance, when you trigger the foot- warmer,
it will change from liquid state to solid state.

There happens the reverse phenomenon,
meaning that it will liberate heat.
If you want to see how to make sodium acetate,

I invite you to watch Experimentboy's video
on this topic (FR).
So the reason for which ice cools down drinks
is not especially because they are cold,
but mostly because they melt.

That's it, I hope you'll watch your ice cubes
with a different look this summer.
Thanks and see you soon !
